title: Djouce Mountain Hike Walking Route

images.title: Rob Hurson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: J.B. Malone memorial and boardwalk

images.title: Joe King, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: J B Malone Memorial

images.title: Rob Hurson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The boardwalk leading up White Hill (Wicklow, Ireland). The bog's badly eroded here due to the popularity of the Wicklow Way, so they've laid down old railway sleepers to give it some protection.

images.title: Rob Hurson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This was taken on White Hill. The three hills in the middle ground are Scarr (Scor / "Sharp Rock"), Knocknacloghoge (Cnoc na Clochóige / "Hill with Stony Bits") and Luggala (Log an Lágh / "Hollow of the Hill"). The Turlough Hill pumped hydro station is silhouetted straight ahead, while Tonelagee (Tóin le Gaoithe / "Arse to the Wind") is pushing up into the cloud.

images.title: K.ristof, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ballinastoe, Co. Wicklow, Ireland

images.title: David Quinn / Wicklow Way
images.caption: Wicklow Way. Taken from where the Wicklow Way diverges from the path leading to Djouce mountain summit. Visible on the right-hand side is the Great Sugar Loaf.

images.title: Rob Hurson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Summit of Djouce Mountain

images.title: Jimmy Harris, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Djouce summit

description: This walk climbs to Djouce Mountain in the Wicklow Mountains. You can start the walk from the car park at the J.B Malone Memorial which is located just east of Lough Tay on the edge of the Ballinastoe Forest . It's a lovely spot to start from with fine views over the Lough to Luggala . From here you can follow a boardwalk along a section of the Wicklow Way . Follow the trails north and they will take you through the forest to White Hill and then onto the summit of Djouce. At the 725 m (2,379 ft) summit you will find a trig point and stunning views across to the other Wicklow mountains.
